concern:
So this is a long story and I'm currently in a bit of a unique situation because of which there's no one irl who i can ask for reliable advice so as much as reddit is really not the place to be asking for advice on life changing decisions i've got no other options and here we go.

**TDLR:  was a good student, went to horrible uni and tried to survive. now burnt out, looking to transfer but bc of horrid uni application is fucked. thinking of dropping out want to know abt how likelihood of job opportunities for foreign drop-outs. read passages marked \* for a longer summary**

**\*** The story basically goes that, I am an Indian citizen, but i've lived my whole life abroad so i know as much about India as ur next door neighbour + like 5%, okay. At the end of high school, I blindly trusted my parents' suggestion and got into and started attending a top 10 indian uni which has now become the single worst decision i've ever made in my entire life.

As it turned out, my uni is 100% fucked up. I could go on abt it for days but we don't have time to give a short summary of the vibes: extreme mismanagement of an institution, horrible facilities/classrooms, no sense of academic integrity, poor teaching, no sort of proper functioning basic 'services' like student welfare or career counselors provided, straight up illegal shit like holding classes in a construction site, the fact that you DON'T HAVE WIFI NOR DOES MOBILE DATA WORK BC NETWORK IS SO BAD on campus, the list goes on.

Getting back to my situation, my first year was online and EVERYONE cheated on EVERYTHING but I didn't know how to so I didn't and ended up with the lower side of decent kinda grades (mainly bc most of the syllabus was geared to start off from what was taught in the Indian curriculum that I obv didn't study and so there were large gaps in my knowledge that I wasn't even aware of). For detail, I averaged a 8.33/10 CGPA.

In my 2nd year, we went irl, I got my shit together, worked super hard but bc there is literally no sense of fair grading and cheating is rampant at my uni, so my efforts have only given mediocre results. (I got a 8.73/10 GPA in that sem, now averaging 8.46). This added with overwork (my uni is 6 days a week, 1 month holiday for summer, 1 week for winter, sometimes we do 7 days a week working and the semesters are back-to-back i.e. after the last day of sem 3, the next day is sem 4), I am super burned out rn with v low morale.

**\*** I've decided to transfer but I have a v weak application, I only focused on studying and I do computer science so I need projects/stuff to appear as a suitable candidate. I am generally quiet and mainly focused on self-learning bc of my low-quality classes so my letter of recommendations is also super weak. Ofc i do have potential, i am smart, i am hard working, i am capable. But my situation for the past 2 years has been HORRENDOUS and unfortunately no uni is going to understand that. After all i go to a top10 uni, hundreds of fully capable candidates graduate from there every year and i am the only one making excuses.

**\*** My only other option is to drop out. But my main priority is to leave India bc I cannot live here on my own like i don't know the language or the customs, etc and unlike every other country i've lived in you can't just google get straight forward answers for things in India which is the only survival method i've learnt. Which basically means if I drop out, I would have to learn computer science on my own and get a job abroad and i've never heard of anyone do that or the prospects of that path so I am super unsure.

This post has been an absolute mess but if anyone could help i'd appreciate it so so much.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm so glad you're here. I'm here to listen and support you, and I encourage you to share whatever's on your mind or heart. Take your time, and know that everything we discuss is confidential and nonjudgmental.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m just really overwhelmed with everything going on, and I’m not even sure where to start with all the mess in my head.
I'm really glad you're here, and it sounds like you're feeling quite overwhelmed. Would it be helpful to start by just sharing what's been on your mind lately?
Yeah, I think that’d be good. I’ve just been stuck in this spiral of stress about my uni situation and future, and I’m kinda lost on what to do next.

It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed with your current situation, and that's totally understandable. It's okay to feel lost right now, and I'm here to help you navigate those feelings. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your uni situation and future that's been causing you so much stress?
Hey, yeah, it’s just been a lot. My uni experience has been a complete disaster, and it’s left me feeling burned out and clueless about where I’m headed, you know?

It sounds like you've been going through a really tough time with your university experience, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure of your direction. I'm here to listen and support you as you work through these feelings, and I'm curious to hear more about what's been contributing to this sense of burnout and uncertainty for you.

Hey, yeah, thanks for being here to listen. It’s just been a mix of awful conditions at uni and feeling like my hard work isn’t getting me anywhere, which has totally drained me and made me question everything about my path forward.

That sounds like a really difficult experience to navigate, and it's understandable that you're feeling drained and uncertain about your path forward. I'm curious, what would it look like for you to feel like your hard work is paying off and your path forward is clear?

Hey, honestly, I think it would feel like finally being in an environment where my efforts are recognized and I’m actually learning and growing, you know? Like, having a clear idea of steps I can take that lead somewhere, instead of just spinning my wheels in a messed-up system.

That sounds like a really important goal for you, and it's completely understandable that you want to feel like your efforts are recognized and that you're learning and growing. What steps do you think you could take to start creating that environment for yourself?

Hey, I’m not really sure, to be honest, because I feel so stuck right now. I’ve been thinking about transferring to a better uni or even dropping out, but I’m scared neither option will work out and I’ll just end up in a worse spot.

That fear is completely understandable, and it's important to weigh the potential risks and benefits of each option. What would it mean for you to take a small step toward exploring either transferring or taking a break, without fully committing to either option just yet?

Hey, I guess taking a small step would mean like, maybe researching some unis abroad or looking into what kind of resources or support I could get if I took a break, you know? I’m just kinda nervous about even starting that process because I don’t wanna get my hopes up and then have it all fall apart again.

That's a valid concern, and it's okay to feel nervous about taking that first step. One small action you could consider is setting aside a specific time this week to look into one university abroad, just to get a sense of what the process might involve. Alternatively, you could start by reaching out to one person in your support network, whether that's a family member or a friend, to talk through your thoughts and feelings. Which of these options feels like the smallest step you could take right now?

Hey, I think starting with just looking into one university abroad feels a bit more doable right now, you know? I’m kinda hesitant to talk to family or friends yet because I don’t wanna deal with their opinions until I have a clearer idea of what I even want.

That's a great choice, and it sounds like a manageable first step. If you're comfortable sharing, could you tell me a bit more about what aspects of this university you're interested in researching? And if you don't mind me asking, how would you like to structure your research - perhaps setting aside a specific time or day this week to focus on this?

Hey, I think I’d wanna start by just checking out their computer science program, like what kind of courses they offer and if they have any specific requirements for international transfers, you know? And maybe setting aside like an hour or two this weekend to dig into their website and see what’s what would work for me, since I’ve got a bit of downtime then.

That sounds like a solid plan, and it's good that you're thinking about how to structure your research. How would you like to handle any potential challenges that might come up during your research, like feeling overwhelmed or not finding the information you need?

Hey, I guess if I start feeling overwhelmed, I could just take a break and come back to it later, or maybe jot down what’s stressing me out to sort through it, you know? And if I can’t find the info I need, I might try emailing their admissions office or looking for forums where other students might’ve shared their experiences.

Hey, I appreciate having a plan for those potential hiccups, it makes me feel a bit more in control. So, do you think checking in next session about how this research went would be helpful, just to keep me on track?

Hey, I’m glad we’ve got this plan in place too, it really helps ease my mind a bit. Yeah, checking in next session sounds like a good idea to keep me accountable and talk through anything that comes up.
Hey, I'm really glad we’ve got this set up, and I feel a bit more confident moving forward. Thanks for helping me think through this stuff—do you have any other quick tips before we wrap up?
